This proposal seeks funding for a second five-year term (Phase II) of the NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center for Advanced Forestry Systems (CAFS) sites including the North Carolina State University (lead), Virginia Tech, Oregon State University and Purdue University. The collaborative research conducted under the CAFS umbrella focuses on optimizing genetic and cultural systems to produce high-quality raw materials for new and existing forest products industries.

Over the past 50 years, much forestry research has taken place in university-based, industry-supported, cooperative research programs. These "coops" continue be extraordinarily successful at achieving research and technological advances on topics of great relevance to the forest industry. However, the ability to focus on specific disciplinary topics in response to industrial guidance is also a limitation. Many of the problems and opportunities facing forestry today, bridge disciplinary and regional boundaries. For technological advances to be made, it is necessary to approach research questions on multiple spatial and temporal scales, including the molecular, cellular, individual-tree, stand, and ecosystem levels. The proposed Center (CAFS) has been successful at providing the administrative structure and funding that has allowed scientists from these existing cooperatives to initiate much need cross-disciplinary research in areas of genetics, site manipulation, and growth and yield modeling. The proposal presents a plan for the 2nd five-year phase for the four original university CAFS sites, North Carolina State, Oregon State, Purdue, and Virginia Tech. This proposal also serves as a research and administrative template for the other five university sites that have joined CAFS since its interception in late 2007.

The research conducted by CAFS increases the competitiveness of forest products industries and forest landowners by solving problems on multiple temporal and spatial scales and determining fundamental solutions that transcend traditional species, regional, and disciplinary boundaries. Member organizations of the Center benefit by becoming knowledgeable about a wider range of technological capabilities. In addition, technology transfer between Center scientists and member personnel fosters rapid implementation of new technologies. The broader scientific community benefits through refereed publications and presentations at scientific meetings. During the Phase II period, graduate student training will continue to be featured in Center research and technology transfer. Aggressive recruiting for graduate students among under-represented groups will be conducted, increasing the diversity of the workforce for both academia and industry in this traditionally diversity-deficient discipline. Opportunities will continue to be sought to involve undergraduate students in Center research activities, exposing them to the excitement of forest science and encouraging them to pursue graduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAFS Project 10.33. Use of Stable Isotopes to Trace the Fate of Applied Nitrogen in Forest Plantations to Evaluate Fertilizer Efficiency and Ecosystem Impacts

All enhanced efficiency nitrogen (N) containing fertilizers (EEFs) used in this study reduced fertilizer N loss, generally via the loss pathway of ammonia (NH3) volatilization, from the ecosystem immediately following fertilization compared to urea, regardless of the timing of application. Although fertilizer N loss from urea was positively correlated with certain weather variables, correlations were generally weak or negatively correlated with all EEFs. Lower N losses using EEFs directly translated to an increase in fertilizer N remaining in the ecosystem compared to urea. These finding provide a high level of certainty that using EEFs in intensively managed loblolly pine forests across the southeastern United States will increase fertilizer N retention for these systems compared to the traditional form of N, urea, regardless of the season of application. 

CAFS Project 14.49. Do Below Ground Processes Such as Soil Nutrient Dynamics, Root Nutrient Uptake and Carbon Allocation Patterns Explain Differences in Growth, Productivity, and Carrying Capacity of Loblolly Pine Plantation in the Southern United States and Brazil

This study demonstrated the need to understand the complex interactions between genotypes and the environment. Results suggest that genetic gains from varieties may differ between sites (genetic by environment interaction). The responses of the varieties to silvicultural intensity were similar for stem growth and different for crown traits. In particular, the large differences in crown dimensions may result in significant differences in stem diameter and consequently stand productivity later in the rotation. The greater stem growth of the varieties relative to the OP and CMP families was influenced more by the site conditions than by the effect of silvicultural intensity. However, results are currently limited due to the young stage of stand development, so additional research for these trials, particularly at the onset of canopy closure, will improve our understanding of stand dynamics and intraspecific competition of the different ideotypes. 

CAFS Project 14.48. Developing a Region-wide Modeling System for Estimating Future Productivity of Loblolly Pine Plantations

A region-wide modeling system for projecting future productivity of loblolly pine plantations, including effects of enhanced genotypes, intensive silvicultural practices, future climate and CO2 scenarios was developed for this project. Regional base-line growth models with general response to silvicultural treatment functions have been developed, and model relating site index to biophysical variables. Simulations of forest response to climate variation and CO2 enrichment have also been conducted. This combined modeling framework will provide forest managers the ability to utilize growth and yield models to estimate productivity for a gradient of inputs, soil types and climate zones. These models will provide managers the ability to evaluate the likely impacts of climate variation and CO2 enrichment on the future productivity of loblolly pine across the southeastern United States. Results will be incorporated into a regional-level decision support system that will aid in strategic decision making for forest managers.
